sect1.title: Filters
sect1.para: There are two kinds of filters in WinMerge: file filters for filtering files and folders in folder compare and line filters for ignoring lines from files before comparing.

sect2.title: Regular expressions
sect2.para: Filters are based on regular expressions (regexps). Each line filter or file filter rule is regexp which is matched against file/folder name or line.
Regexps can be very complex to read. Luckily most file filtering needs are for file extensions. File filters installed with WinMerge have many useful examples.

sect2.title: File filters
sect2.para: A file filter is a set of rules saved to one file. Every file and folder is tested against all these rules before comparing. Files and folders that match the rules are excluded if it is an inclusive filter, or included if it is an exclusive filter.

tip.para: Ignored items have "Skipped" status in folder compare. User can select them to visible or hidden from View menu. Usually its wise to keep skipped items hidden.

sect2.para:
WinMerge's filtering system allows only one filter set to be active at a time. Active filter set can be selected from Open-dialog or from menu: Tools
Filters . Also empty filter can be selected when no folders or files are ignored.

sect3.title: Filter files
sect3.para: Filter files are normal text files, with an extension of .flt. Files have defined format which is explained later in this chapter. Filters-dialog allows creating new filter files based on template file. Filter files can be created from the scrach but using template file is the recommended way to create a new filter.
Filter files have two possible locations:

listitem.para: "Filters" subfolder in the WinMerge program folder. E.g. C:\Program Files\WinMerge\Filters.

User-defined folder. Selected in Options ( Edit
Options > System > Filter Folder). By default it is My Documents -folder.

important.para: With WinMerge 2.5.4 and later filter files should not be anymore placed to profile folder like with earlier versions. Using user-defined folder for filter files provices more flexibility and easier access to filter files. WinMerge still reads filters from profile folder for backwards compatibility.

sect3.para: First part of filter file defines name and basic functionality of the filter:

name: Example filter def: includewhere def: is:
include - inclusive filter. This filter type filters out files and folders that match rules in filter.
exclude - exclusive filter. This filter type lets through files and folders that match rules in filter.
When using exclusive filter its worth noting that the filter must contain rule to include all wanted subfolders. Usually its wise to use this rule to include all subfolders:
There can be one filter rule in one line. And rule cannot be split to several lines. Common format for one filter line is like this:

Rule begins with "f:" if it matches for filenames and "d:" if it matches for folder names. (d comes from "directory".) Filenames are given to filter as is, there are no special characters added. But for folder names there must be "\\" in begin of folder name. This is done clearly to separate folder names and filenames. "##" is a comment separator, all characters in line after that are ignored by WinMerge.

note.para: File filter rules are case-insensitive. Rule .\bat$ matches to winmerge.bat and compare.BAT.

sect3.para: So simple filters can be for example:

example.title: Simple filefilter rules
example.screen: f: \.cpp$ ## Match *.cpp files f: \.h$ ## Match *.h files f: ^My ## Match My*.* files f: Dlg\. ## Match *Dlg.* files d: \\test$ ## Match 'test' directories

sect3.para: Line begin or -end marker ("^" or "$") is usually required filter to work correctly. Dot in filename must be "escaped" with "\" so "\." means dot in filename.

note.para: Don't forget "$" at end. It marks end of folder- or filename and without it rule may not work like expected. While "\.c$" matches with only filenames having extension .c "\.c" matches all extensions beginning with "c" (.cpp, .com, etc).

sect3.para: Since file filter rules are regular expressions more complex rules are also possible. Following few rules show some possibilities for more complex rules:

example.title: More complex file filter rules
example.screen: f: ^\.#.*$ ## .#filename.version files f: Dlg\.c(pp)?$ ## *Dlg.c & *Dlg.cpp files f: ^I.*\.h$ ## I*.h files f: Srv[1-9]\.def$ ## *Srv1.def - *Srv9.def files f: ^[h,k,m] ## h*.* & k*.* & m*.* files

sect3.para: WinMerge ignores most whitespace characters in rules definition lines. However comment must always start with one or more whitespace character (space or tabulator) and comment-marker (##). ## can be used as part of rule if there is no whitespace character before it.

sect2.title: Line filters
sect2.para: Line filters can be used to ignore single lines from compared files. Line filters are handy when user doesn't want to compare comments or certain generated code. For example version control system (time)stamps.

important.para: Line filter rule ignores single line it matches. It is not possible to ignore partial lines or several lines with file filter rule.

sect2.para: In file compare ignored lines are shown with own colors to differentiate them from other differences. User can see these differences but cannot select or merge them.

Line filter rules are regular expressions like file filter rules. Since filter matches if any part of line matches it is usually recommended to add begin ("^") or end ("$") marker to rule. Or both markers if exact line is wanted to filtered.

tip.para: There are some troubles with "$" and end-of-line. One way to work-around these troubles is to use "\W$" when possible.

sect2.para:
Rules can be added and edited in Filters-dialog (Menu: Tools
Filters ). In editbox, give one rule per line. Compare results are not updated automatically after changing line filter rules. User can update compare results by selecting Edit
Refresh or F5.
Maximum length for linefilter (all lines in dialog) is 255 characters.
